g.text: Do Not Cite, Quote or Distribute
Role of digitalization and advanced control systems
significantly reduce energy infrastructure investments while enhancing
progress has been made in the development of technologies essential for the transition to a digitalized
energy control paradigm, although the full implementation is still under development. Electrification
and the increased integration of the
electricity system with other systems will fundamentally transform
the operational and planning paradigm of future energy infrastructure. A fully intelligent and
sophisticated coordination of the multiple systems through smart control will support this pa
shift. This shift will provide significant savings through better utilization of existing infrastructure
locally, regionally, nationally, and internationally. Supply system reliability will be enhanced through
the potential to increase energy efficiency through a combination of technologies that gather and analyse
data and consequently optimize energy use in real
driven control of energy system operations
including the internet, wireless networks, computers, software, middleware, smart sensors, internet of
things components, and dedicated technological developments
transition will raise standardization and cybersecurity issues,
given that digitalization can become a
single point of failure for the complete system
peer energy trading based on blockchain is expected to be one of the key elements
. This trading will enable consumers to drive
operation and future design, increasing overall system efficiency and security of supply while
reducing emissions without sacrificing users privacy
deployed with smart contracts, this concept will be suitable for energy systems invo
participants, where a prerequisite is digitalization (e.g., smart meters, end
eufel et al. 2019; Juhar and Khaled 2018)
System benefits of flexibility technologies and advanced control systems
New sources of flexibility and advanced control systems provide a significant opportunity to reduce
enhancing operating efficiency and reducing energy infrastructure
carbon generation investments, while continuing to meet security requirements (
). In the U.S, for example, one study found that flexibility in buildings alone could re
et al. 2021). Key means for creating savings are associated with the following:
system control will enable more efficient, real
balancing. This balancing has historically been provided by conventional fossil
estment in low carbon/renewable generation capacity:
absorb or export surplus electricity, thus reducing or avoiding energy curtailment and reducing the
carbon capacity such as nuclear and fossil
. For example, one study found that flexibility technologies and
rol systems could reduce the need for nuclear power by 14 GW and offshore wind by
System flexibility can reduce energy demand peaks, reducing
the required generation capacity to maintain the security of supply, producing significant savings
Deferral or avoidance of electricity network reinforcement/addition:
supported by advanced control systems can provide significant savings in investment in electricity
